Literature Review: Fatty acid-binding proteins (FABPs) have emerged as a crucial family of molecules in mammalian lipid metabolism and cellular function. These small, intracellular proteins have been the subject of extensive research over the past few decades, revealing their multifaceted roles in various physiological processes and their potential implications in disease states.FABPs are characterized by their ability to bind long-chain fatty acids (FAs) with high affinity. The mammalian FABP family consists of ten distinct isoforms, each with tissue-specific expression patterns and unique functional properties. These isoforms include liver (L-FABP), intestinal (I-FABP), heart (H-FABP), adipocyte (A-FABP), epidermal (E-FABP), ileal (Il-FABP), brain (B-FABP), myelin (M-FABP), testis (T-FABP), and adipocyte satiety factor (S-FABP) [1]. Despite their diverse tissue distribution, all FABPs share a highly conserved tertiary structure, consisting of a β-barrel formation with a central ligand-binding pocket [2].Initially, FABPs were primarily studied for their role in intracellular fatty acid transport. They were thought to facilitate the movement of hydrophobic fatty acids through the aqueous cytoplasm, thereby regulating their availability for various cellular processes. However, subsequent research has revealed that FABPs play a much broader role in lipid metabolism and cellular function [3].One of the key functions of FABPs is their involvement in the regulation of gene expression. Studies have shown that FABPs can interact with nuclear receptors, such as peroxisome proliferator-activated receptors (PPARs), and modulate their transcriptional activity [4]. This interaction allows FABPs to influence the expression of genes involved in lipid metabolism, inflammation, and cell differentiation. For example, A-FABP has been found to enhance the transcriptional activity of PPARγ, a key regulator of adipocyte differentiation and glucose homeostasis [5].Beyond their role in gene regulation, FABPs have been implicated in various signaling pathways within their cells of expression. They have been shown to interact with kinases, such as c-Jun N-terminal kinase (JNK), and modulate inflammatory responses [6]. This involvement in cellular signaling extends the functional repertoire of FABPs beyond simple lipid transport and suggests a more complex role in cellular homeostasis.Interestingly, recent evidence has indicated that some FABPs may also have extracellular functions. Studies have detected FABPs in circulation, suggesting that they may be secreted by cells and potentially act as signaling molecules in distant tissues [7]. This discovery opens up new avenues for understanding the systemic effects of FABPs and their potential role in inter-organ communication.The ligand-binding capabilities of FABPs have also been found to extend beyond long-chain fatty acids. Some FABP isoforms have been shown to bind other lipophilic molecules, including eicosanoids, retinoids, and even some drugs [8]. This broader binding repertoire suggests that FABPs may play a role in the transport and metabolism of various lipid-soluble compounds, potentially influencing diverse cellular processes.The involvement of FABPs in systemic metabolism has become increasingly apparent. Studies have linked FABP expression and function to various metabolic disorders, including obesity, insulin resistance, and type 2 diabetes. For instance, elevated levels of A-FABP in circulation have been associated with an increased risk of metabolic syndrome and cardiovascular disease [9]. Furthermore, genetic studies in mice have demonstrated that FABP deficiency can protect against diet-induced obesity and insulin resistance, highlighting the potential of FABPs as therapeutic targets in metabolic disorders [10].In addition to their role in metabolic diseases, FABPs have been implicated in inflammation-related disorders and cancer. The ability of FABPs to modulate inflammatory signaling pathways has led to investigations into their potential involvement in conditions such as atherosclerosis and inflammatory bowel disease. In cancer research, altered expression of specific FABP isoforms has been observed in various tumor types, suggesting a potential role in cancer progression and metastasis.In conclusion, the family of mammalian fatty acid-binding proteins has emerged as a multifunctional group of molecules with diverse roles in cellular and systemic physiology. From their initial characterization as simple fatty acid transporters, our understanding of FABPs has expanded to encompass their involvement in gene regulation, cellular signaling, and systemic metabolism. The growing body of evidence linking FABPs to various disease states underscores their potential as both biomarkers and therapeutic targets. As research in this field continues to evolve, it is likely that new functions and applications of FABPs will be discovered, further cementing their importance in mammalian biology and medicine.
